short-title.#text:
Southeast Arizona Land Exchange
			 and Conservation Act of 2013

text.#text:
This Act may be cited
			 as the
The table of contents for this Act is as follows:

toc-entry.#text: Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents.

Sec. 5. Conveyance and management of non-Federal
				land.
Sec. 6. Value adjustment payment to United States.
Sec. 9. Conveyances to town of Superior, Arizona.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds that—

text.#text: the land exchange furthers public objectives referenced in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: including—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 206 of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976/s:206

text.#text:
promoting
			 significant job and other economic opportunities in a part of the State of
			 Arizona that has a long history of mining, but is currently experiencing high
			 unemployment rates and economic difficulties;

facilitating the
			 development of a world-class domestic copper deposit capable of meeting a
			 significant portion of the annual United States demand for this strategic and
			 important mineral, in an area which has already been subject to mining
			 operations;

securing Federal
			 ownership and protection of land with significant fish and wildlife,
			 recreational, scenic, water, riparian, cultural, and other public
			 values;

assisting more
			 efficient Federal land management via Federal acquisition of land for addition
			 to the Las Cienegas and San Pedro National Conservation Areas, and to the Tonto
			 and Coconino National Forests;

providing
			 opportunity for community expansion and economic diversification adjacent to
			 the towns of Superior, Miami, and Globe, Arizona; and

protecting the
			 cultural resources and other values of the Apache Leap escarpment located near
			 Superior, Arizona; and

the land exchange
			 is, therefore, in the public interest.

It
			 is the purpose of this Act to authorize, direct, facilitate, and expedite the
			 exchange of land between Resolution Copper and the United States.
In this Act:

if so requested by

			 from existing drill pads located outside the Area, if the activities would not

if so requested by

			 (but not within the Oak Flat Campground), if the activities are conducted from

			 and noise impacts on the Campground.

text.#text:
In addition to the conveyance of the non-Federal land to
			 the United States under this Act, and as a condition of the land exchange,
			 Resolution Copper shall surrender to the United States, without compensation,
			 the rights held by Resolution Copper under the mining laws and other laws of
			 the United States to commercially extract minerals under Apache Leap.

The first report is required to be submitted not later than February 15 of the first calendar year beginning after the date of commencement of production of valuable locatable minerals in commercial quantities from such Federal land. The reports shall be submitted February 15 of each calendar year thereafter.

text.#text: Amounts in the special fund established pursuant to

Subject to valid existing rights, Apache
			 Leap and any land acquired by the United States under this Act are withdrawn
			 from all forms of—

entry,
			 appropriation, or disposal under the public land laws;

location, entry,
			 and patent under the mining laws; and

disposition under
			 the mineral leasing, mineral materials, and geothermal leasing laws.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall manage Apache Leap to preserve the natural character of Apache Leap and to protect archeological and cultural resources located on Apache Leap.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: may issue to Resolution Copper special use permits allowing Resolution Copper to carry out underground activities (other than the commercial extraction of minerals) under the surface of Apache Leap that the
determines would not disturb the surface of the land, subject to any terms and conditions that the
may require.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: may allow use of the surface of Apache Leap for installation of fences, signs, monitoring devices, or other measures necessary to protect the health and safety of the public, protect resources located on Apache Leap, or to ensure that activities conducted under
do not affect the surface of Apache Leap.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Southeast Arizona Land Exchange and Conservation Act of 2013/s:8/ss:a/p:2

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , in consultation with affected Indian tribes, the Town, Resolution Copper, and other interested members of the public, shall prepare a management plan for Apache Leap.

text.#text: Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Southeast Arizona Land Exchange and Conservation Act of 2013/s:8/ss:b/p:1

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall consider whether additional measures are necessary to—

text.#text: In preparing the plan under

protect the
			 cultural, archaeological, or historical resources of Apache Leap, including
			 permanent or seasonal closures of all or a portion of Apache Leap; and

provide access for
			 recreation.

The provisions of this section shall not impose
			 additional restrictions on mining activities carried out by Resolution Copper
			 adjacent to, or outside of, the Apache Leap area beyond those otherwise
			 applicable to mining activities on privately owned land under Federal, State,
			 and local laws, rules and regulations.

text.#text: if Resolution Copper notifies the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , as amended (
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 206(d) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976/s:206/ss:d

text.#text:
Nothing in this Act shall interfere with,
			 limit, or otherwise impair, the unpatented mining claims or rights currently
			 held by Resolution Copper on the Federal land, nor in any way change, diminish,
			 qualify, or otherwise impact Resolution Copper’s rights and ability to conduct
			 activities on the Federal land under such unpatented mining claims and the
			 general mining laws of the United States, including the permitting or
			 authorization of such activities.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: concerned and Resolution Copper may correct, by mutual agreement, any minor errors in any map, acreage estimate, or description of any land conveyed or exchanged under this Act.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: concerned and Resolution Copper mutually agree otherwise.

text.#text: If there is a conflict between a map, an acreage estimate, or a description of land in this Act, the map shall control unless the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall file and make available for public inspection in the Office of the Supervisor, Tonto National Forest, each map referred to in this Act.

text.#text: On the date of enactment of this Act, the

current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To facilitate the efficient extraction of mineral
		  resources in southeast Arizona by authorizing and directing an exchange of
		  Federal and non-Federal land, and for other purposes.
